awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Measuring the Composition and Structure of Rocky Extrasolar Bodies
awd_abstract_narration:
White dwarf stars collected leftover rocky material from planetary systems that orbited their host stars until the stars reached their end of life and caused their planets to break apart.  These "polluted" white dwarf stars can be studied using telescopes that measure their light broken down into different wavelengths. The signatures of different chemical elements appear at different wavelengths.  The chemical elements found telescopically give information about the bulk chemical composition of rocky material in those disintegrating planets.  The types of rocks present in the planets can be reconstructed from the bulk chemical composition.  The scientists propose studies that will use spectral observations to find more polluted white dwarf stars and assess the water and rocky content of the planetary bodies that orbited the white dwarf stars, looking for signs of earth-like plate tectonics in the planetary bodies, and studying pathways for material to travel from the planetary bodies to the host stars.  This project supports the mission of the NSF by promoting our understanding of the composition of planets orbiting other stars.  The investigators will include students who participate in the UC San Diego STARS program and other institutional initiatives aimed at underrepresented groups in their research efforts.


The investigators will continue spectroscopic observations of candidate white dwarf stars to identify those that are most heavily polluted.  Estimates of the water content for all parent bodies polluting white dwarfs will be made in combination with an assessment of the water content in white dwarfs being polluted by substantial quantities of hydrogen. From a sample of nearly 100 white dwarfs, they will estimate the occurrence rate for water-rich rocky bodies in other planetary systems.  For the subset of white dwarf stars that are being polluted by rocky crust and mantle material, they will conduct a deep search for the chemical signature of plate tectonics. Detections or deep limits on Ba and Sr will inform the possibility of plate tectonics for massive differentiated rocky bodies outside the Solar System.  Dynamical simulations will examine the ability of collisional processes to strip massive differentiated rocky bodies of their outermost crust and mantle layers, and then track this ejecta and the body it originated from to explore how white dwarfs get polluted by material from specific regions of a rocky body.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project aimed to provide a comprehensive assessment of the types of
rocky material and planetary body structures found outside of the solar
system. Our technique relied on the unique information afforded by dead
"white dwarf" stars that are in the process of consuming material from
their planetary systems. Colloquially known as "polluted white dwarf
stars", these objects enable us to measure the composition of planetary
system material at an atomic level -- something typically reserved for
rocks found on Earth or retrieved during select space missions like
Apollo or OSIRIS-Rex.

The first phase of this project demanded the identification of as many
polluted white dwarf stars as could be found. This entailed a sweeping
optical spectroscopic survey conducted primarily with the Lick,
Magellan, and Gemini Observatories. Of order 1,000 previously unknown
white dwarf stars were observed and close to 100 polluted systems were
identified. White dwarfs with no evidence for planetary systems have
been published in auxiliary surveys dedicated to Galactic and stellar
evolution studies and are otherwise having their data released into
public repositories.

With our sample of high priority white dwarf planetary systems we began
the second phase of dedicated follow-up observations. Detailed
spectroscopic data were obtained at the Keck and Magellan Observatories
and in select cases observations were obtained with the Hubble Space
Telescope. State-of-the art atmospheric modeling revealed the abundances
of various elements like C, O, Mg, Al, Si, Ca, Ti, Cr, Fe, and Ni.

These measurements allowed us to assess the chemical nature of the
planetary system material observed and sometimes enabled a determination
of where in a massive rocky body the material originated from (e.g.,
core, mantle, or crust). Publication efforts have included specific
systems worthy of individual note -- e.g., the discovery of a white
dwarf being polluted by material rich in beryllium or another white
dwarf that could potentially be accreting two drastically different
rocky bodies simultaneously -- and collections of systems to obtain a
broader view on exoplanetary rocky material -- e.g., the assessment that
most white dwarfs accrete material that is compositionally similar to
the basic building blocks seen in the solar system. Publication of
detailed system characterization results continues and will include an
assessment of the amount of water present in rocky material from other
planetary systems, the amount of biologically-relevant elements present
in exoplanetary crusts, and the amount of carbon- and oxygen-bearing
ices present in exoplanetary rocks.

Parallel to the above efforts was a computational study on the dynamical
history of polluted white dwarf systems and insights into their
polluters. Computer simulations explored how planetary system bodies
change their orbits, collide, and spread ejecta as their host star dies.
A major result from such work shows how some of the most heavily
polluted white dwarf stars may be accreting the remains of exoplanetary
moons similar to the Galilean satellites orbiting Jupiter. Continuing
work will provide details on if ejecta fragments from planetary crusts
and cores can eventually be accreted by their host white dwarf star.

Student involvement was featured throughout this work, typically
including individuals from underrepresented groups within the sciences.
Such efforts often took advantage of institutional programs that helped
elevate low socioeconomic status people to higher levels of academia. In
total, roughly a dozen students ranging from undergraduates to graduates
participated in this project.
